Stem: Alpha Standardized Science G7.10 Created By STC 11 The following section focuses on an investigation of different substances that make icy sidewalks safer. Read the information below and use it to answer the three selected-response questions and one constructed- response question that follow. . . During winter, a class of students in Massachusetts completed an investigation to determine how to make icy sidewalks safer. They tested four substances to see whether the substances could melt ice. The information the students gathered about each substance is shown in Table 1. The students measured how long it took each substance to melt a different icy area on each of three days. All the icy areas the students tested were the same size. The data the students collected are shown in Table 2. Sand made the icy areas less slippery, but it did not melt the ice. Some of the substances harmed the grass. The following spring, the grass was brown and unhealthy next to the areas where sodium chloride and calcium chloride had been tested. However, the grass was green and healthy next to the areas where urea and sand had been tested. The chemical formula for urea is CH N O. Which model represents a molecule of urea? 1 4 2 A B C D Look at the chemical equation for table salt. 2Na + CI 2NaCI →

DCI Justification: Grade-appropriate content but routine application.
CCC Justification: Pattern recognition implicitly involved but not explicitly required.
Key Recommendation: Push beyond recall — require students to reason with science ideas, not just identify them.

Stem: Many vitamins are found in nature. One such vitamin is vitamin D. Our skin makes vitamin D when it is exposed to sunlight. Vitamin D is also synthetically made in factories in the form of pills. Synthetic substances are made from natural resources and are then processed and changed chemically. These synthetically made vitamin D pills acts as an equally good source of nutrition as the natural vitamin D in geographic locations where people are less exposed to sunlight. Is it useful to synthesize a compound that is found naturally in nature?
Choices: A) No, since it is more expensive than harvesting natural substances from nature., B) Yes, over harvesting from nature could damage the environment., C) No, synthesized substances are never effective as natural substances., D) Yes, a synthesized compound is more effective than a naturally available one. Stem: Many consumers are aware of environmental and human impacts concerning the products they buy and use. Cotton is a well-known fabric material. Hemp is a plant that produces a fiber that can be manufactured to produce fabric similar to cotton. What is the most logical conclusion based on the information in the table? Hemp vs. Cotton - Cotton requires twice as much land and water as hemp. - Hemp produces two times more fiber per acre than cotton. - Cotton requires pesticide and herbicide for maximum growth. - Hemp requires little to no pesticides for maximum growth - Hemp returns up to 60% of nutrients to the soil when dried in the fields.
Choices: A) A long-term cash crop such as cotton is easier to mass produce and manufacture than hemp., B) Synthetic materials offer a beneficial alternative material to cotton because they are stronger fibers, C) Cotton is less natural than hemp as a clothing fiber because growers use herbicides while growing it., D) Hemp is a beneficial alternative to cotton for creating clothing because it produces more fiber, requires less water, and does not require many pesticides to grow. Stem: E sublimation Jared completes an investigation to show what happens when thermal energy is added to or removed from water. He made the model below to show the results of his investigation. Which statement describes what happened in this experiment? Initial Heat Result added removed
Choices: A) The amount of kinetic energy increased as the heat was removed., B) As more heat was added, the amount of kinetic energy decreased., C) As the heat was removed, the amount of kinetic energy decreased., D) The amount of heat had no effect on the amount of kinetic energy. The following section focuses on how rust forms. Read the information below and use it to answer the three selected-response questions and one constructed- response question that follow. . . At the beginning of summer, some paint was scratched off a student’s bicycle. The exposed metal where the bicycle was scratched had a shiny, silvery color. The student kept the bicycle outside all summer. By the end of summer, the exposed metal had changed to rust, which is dark orange in color. The student did some research to find out what happened to the metal and learned that the bicycle is made of steel, which contains mostly iron. The student conducted two investigations to learn more about the process that changed the steel into rust. Investigation 1: The student placed equal amounts of iron filings (small pieces of iron) into beakers X, Y, and Z. At the start of the investigation, all of the filings were gray. The student added nothing else to beaker X, water to beaker Y, and table salt (NaCl) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) to beaker Z. The student’s observations over a two-day period are shown in the table. Investigation 2: The student combined table salt and hydrogen peroxide in a beaker, added small pieces of steel, and placed a thermometer in the beaker. After one minute, the student measured the mass of the contents in the beaker. The student measured the contents in the beaker again at 10 minutes and discovered the mass had decreased slightly. The student’s observations are shown in the table. 12 When hydrogen peroxide reacts with iron, hydrogen peroxide first breaks apart to form water and oxygen. In the diagrams shown, hydrogen atoms are white and oxygen atoms are gray. Use the law of conservation of mass to determine the number of water and oxygen molecules produced in the reaction. Drag and drop the correct number of water and oxygen molecules into the box. Each molecule may be used once, more than once, or not at all. DRAG & DROP THE ANSWER Note: Use CTRL+D to drag the option via keyboard DIRECTIONS: Read each stimulus. Stem: The rock strata of the Grand Canyon in Arizona contain evidence of approximately 32 percent of the geologic history of Earth and one billion years of fossil life on Earth. In the Grand Canyon, there are clear horizontal layers of different rocks that provide information about where, when, and how they were deposited, long before the canyon was even carved. The Law of Superposition states that sediment is deposited in layers in a sequence, the oldest rocks are on the bottom and the youngest rocks are on the top, similar to the way that sand piles up in an hour glass. This principle is a key part of determining the relative age of a rock layer. The three main rock layer sets in the Grand Canyon are grouped based on position and common composition and 1) Metamorphic basement rocks, 2) The Precambrian Grand Canyon Supergroup, and 3) Paleozoic strata. The three main types of rock are igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic. Igneous rocks are cooled magma (melted rock found underground) or lava (molten rock found above ground). Granite (cooled from magma, known as an intrusive igneous rock) and basalt (cooled from lava, known as an extrusive igneous rock) are two types of igneous rocks. Sedimentary rocks are formed by smaller pieces of sand and mud stuck together in layers. Over time, pressure increases as sediment increases, and minerals help form these rock layers. Metamorphic rocks are formed when sedimentary or igneous rocks change due to exposure to heat and/or pressure. (USGS.gov) What two of these can the Grand Canyon’s rock strata most effectively be used to study?
Choices: A) plate tectonics, B) seismic activity, C) tidal influences, D) tsunami locations E evolutionary biology What best describes the geological significance of scientists finding fossils after drilling into a sedimentary basin?
Scenario Justification: Some context provided but limited scenario complexity.
SEP Justification: Requires constructing explanations or engaging in argumentation.
DCI Justification: Requires applying science understanding in context, beyond simple recall.
